A vehicle that is propelled by one or more electric motors, using energy stored in rechargeable batteries.
An urban concept in which most daily necessities and services, such as work, shopping, education, and healthcare, can be easily reached by a 15-minute walk or bike ride.
The practice of creating structures and using processes that are environmentally responsible and resource-efficient throughout a building's life-cycle.
The phenomenon where metropolitan areas are significantly warmer than their surrounding rural areas due to human activities.
Capable of being decomposed by bacteria or other living organisms and thereby avoiding pollution.
Originating from human activity. Often used to describe climate change caused by humans.
The period used as a baseline for global temperatures, typically referring to the years 1850-1900, before the widespread burning of fossil fuels.
A measure used to compare the emissions from various greenhouse gases based on their Global Warming Potential (GWP).
The process when corals become white after expelling the algae (zooxanthellae) living in their tissues, usually due to the stress of warmer water.
The consumption of a resource faster than it can be replenished.
The concept of fairness or justice between generations. A key principle of sustainable development.
The concept of fairness or justice between people of the same generation, ensuring equitable access to resources for all.
A situation where a household is unable to afford to heat their home to an adequate temperature.
A state of net-zero carbon dioxide emissions. This can be achieved by balancing emissions of carbon dioxide with its removal or by eliminating emissions altogether.

A philosophy of working with, rather than against nature; of protracted and thoughtful observation rather than protracted and thoughtless labor; and of looking at plants and animals in all their functions, rather than treating any area as a single-product system.
The agricultural preparation of soil by mechanical agitation of various types, such as digging, stirring, and overturning.
The hidden flow of water in food or other commodities that are traded from one place to another. It is the amount of water needed to produce a product.
A factor that can change the Earth's energy balance, leading to warming or cooling. Greenhouse gases are a positive forcing.
The process by which water-soluble salts accumulate in the soil, often in coastal areas due to sea level rise, harming agriculture.
The process of conveying a false impression or providing misleading information about how a company's products are more environmentally sound.
An electricity network that uses digital technology to monitor and manage the transport of electricity from all generation sources to meet the varying electricity demands of end-users.
The principle that the introduction of a new product or process whose ultimate effects are disputed or unknown should be resisted.
A semi-liquid mixture, typically of manure, cement, or coal, suspended in water, which can be a source of nitrous oxide and methane.

A policy of producing consumer goods that rapidly become obsolete and so require replacing, achieved by frequent changes in design, termination of the supply of spare parts, and the use of non-durable materials.
The envelope of gases surrounding the Earth or another planet.
The regions of the surface, atmosphere, and hydrosphere of the earth occupied by living organisms.
All the waters on the earth's surface, such as lakes and seas, and sometimes including water over the earth's surface, such as clouds.
Any of the almost spherical concentric regions of matter that make up the earth and its atmosphere, such as the lithosphere and hydrosphere.
The most abundant greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, which also acts as a feedback to the climate.
The study of cyclic and seasonal natural phenomena, especially in relation to climate and plant and animal life (e.g., timing of bird migration or flower blooming).
The process of glaciers shrinking and disappearing, which contributes to sea level rise.
A thick subsurface layer of soil that remains frozen throughout the year, occurring chiefly in polar regions. Thawing permafrost releases methane.
An accounting framework with three parts: social, environmental and financial. Also referred to as the three Ps: people, planet, and profit.
A process that occurs in the absence of oxygen.
A process that requires the presence of oxygen.
Policies and decisions are made by a central authority and implemented at lower levels.
Initiatives and actions that originate from local communities and individuals, influencing policy at a higher level.
Excessive grazing which causes damage to grassland, leading to soil erosion and degradation.
A set of principles focused on waste prevention that encourages the redesign of resource life cycles so that all products are reused.
The process of removing mineral components from saline water to produce fresh water.
A change in the transport mode used, for example, from private cars to public transport or cycling.
The amount of solar radiation reaching a given area.
An illness caused by pathogens and parasites in human populations, transmitted by vectors like mosquitoes. Their range can expand with warming climates.
The world's stocks of natural assets which include geology, soil, air, water and all living things.
The amount of carbon by weight emitted per unit of energy consumed.
A sum of money granted by the state or a public body to help an industry or business keep the price of a commodity or service low (e.g. fossil fuel subsidies).
Crops planted to cover the soil rather than for the purpose of being harvested, helping to manage soil erosion and fertility.
Plastics derived from renewable biomass sources, such as vegetable fats and oils, corn starch, or microbiota.
The delay between a cause (like increased GHG emissions) and its effect (increased temperatures), meaning warming will continue even if emissions stop today.
A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.
A person, group or organization that has interest or concern in an organization or issue.
The components in solar panels that convert sunlight directly into electricity.
Local, national or transnational financingdrawn from public, private and alternative sources of financingthat seeks to support mitigation and adaptation actions that will address climate change.
The chemical processes by which atmospheric nitrogen is assimilated into organic compounds, especially by certain microorganisms.
Water that is safe to drink or to use for food preparation.
A range of water management practices designed to drain surface water in a way that mimics natural processes.
The difference between insolation (sunlight) absorbed by the Earth and energy radiated back to space.
An organism that is not indigenous, or native, to a particular area and can cause great economic and environmental harm to the new area.
A trading partnership, based on dialogue, transparency and respect, that seeks greater equity in international trade.
Fossil fuel energy resources which, at some time prior to the end of their economic life, are no longer able to earn an economic return.
A process, part of the Paris Agreement, for countries and other stakeholders to see where theyre collectively making progress towards meeting the goals of the Agreement  and where theyre not.
The right of peoples to healthy and culturally appropriate food produced through ecologically sound and sustainable methods, and their right to define their own food and agriculture systems.
The process of converting waste materials or useless products into new materials or products of lesser quality and reduced functionality.
The amount of fresh water utilized in the production or supply of the goods and services used by a particular person or group.
The process whereby the character of a poor urban area is changed by wealthier people moving in, improving housing, and attracting new businesses, but often displacing current inhabitants.
The layer of the earth's atmosphere above the troposphere, extending to about 50 km above the earth's surface.
The lowest region of the atmosphere, extending from the earth's surface to a height of about 610 km, where most weather occurs.
A feedback loop that amplifies a change, moving the system further away from its starting state (e.g. melting permafrost releases methane, which causes more warming).
A feedback loop that dampens a change, tending to stabilize a system (e.g. more CO2 can act as a fertilizer for some plants, which then absorb more CO2).
A self-regulating business model that helps a company be socially accountableto itself, its stakeholders, and the public.
The transport of energy by ocean surface waves, and the capture of that energy to do useful work.
A form of hydropower that converts the energy obtained from tides into useful forms of power, mainly electricity.
A reduction in emissions of carbon dioxide or other greenhouse gases made in order to compensate for emissions made elsewhere.
Land use management system in which trees or shrubs are grown around or among crops or pastureland.
The process of transforming by-products, waste materials, useless, or unwanted products into new materials or products of better quality or for better environmental value.
The many and varied benefits that humans freely gain from the natural environment and from properly-functioning ecosystems.
Previously developed land that is not currently in use, which may be potentially contaminated.
Undeveloped land in a city or rural area either used for agriculture or landscape design, or left to evolve naturally.
The collective effects of changes in the Earth's movements on its climate over thousands of years (eccentricity, axial tilt, and precession).
An infectious disease that is transmitted between species from animals to humans (or from humans to animals). Climate change can increase the risk.
A visual framework for sustainable development  shaped like a doughnut  combining the concept of planetary boundaries with the complementary concept of social boundaries.
A device that converts the chemical energy of hydrogen and an oxidizing agent (often oxygen) into electricity.
The negative consequences that arise from the unavoidable risks of climate change, like rising sea levels, prolonged droughts, or extreme weather events.
The practice of growing crops in vertically stacked layers, often indoors in a controlled environment.
The practice of putting an item in the recycling bin even if you're not sure it's recyclable, hoping it will be recycled.
The interface between land and a river or stream. Healthy riparian zones are important for water quality and biodiversity.
The brightening of the night sky caused by street lights and other man-made sources, which has a disruptive effect on natural cycles.
The current geological epoch, which began approximately 11,700 years ago after the last glacial period.
A proposed geological epoch dating from the commencement of significant human impact on Earth's geology and ecosystems.
The change in the distribution of species' boundaries, often moving towards the poles or higher altitudes in response to climate change.
A management strategy in which companies find business opportunities in social problems.

A type of hydroelectric energy storage where water is pumped to a higher elevation reservoir during times of low electricity demand and released to a lower reservoir to generate electricity during peak demand.
A process of evaluating the likely environmental impacts of a proposed project or development, taking into account inter-related socio-economic, cultural and human-health impacts.
The process in which a stress applied to a soil causes densification as air is displaced from the pores between the soil grains, reducing its ability to absorb water.
A systematic assessment of the flows and stocks of materials within a system defined in space and time.
The process of water movement through a plant and its evaporation from aerial parts, such as leaves, stems and flowers.
A measure of how friendly an area is to walking.
A list of greenhouse gas emissions and their sources, and removals by sinks, for a specific country or region.
A condition where the body cannot cool itself enough to maintain a healthy temperature, a growing risk during heatwaves.
An economy made up of a constant stock of physical wealth (capital) and a constant population size.
The ratio of actual electrical energy output over a given period of time to the maximum possible electrical energy output over that period.
The action or process of selling off subsidiary business interests or investments, particularly from fossil fuel companies.
A farming management concept based on observing, measuring and responding to inter and intra-field variability in crops.
Food that is not eaten. The third largest source of human-caused greenhouse gas emissions.
An area of land where all flowing surface water converges to a single point, such as a river mouth, or flows into a larger body of water.
An intentional community of private homes clustered around shared space.
A constantly moving system of deep-ocean circulation driven by temperature and salinity, which moves water around the globe.
Any agent which carries and transmits an infectious pathogen into another living organism.
The design and production of materials, structures, and systems that are modeled on biological entities and processes.
Energy that is generated off-the-main-grid, at or near the point of use.

A principle within the UNFCCC that acknowledges that all states have a shared obligation to address climate change but denotes different capabilities and differing responsibilities of individual states.
The displacement of the upper layer of soil, it is a form of soil degradation.
The process of generating energy in the form of electricity and/or heat from the primary treatment of waste, or the processing of waste into a fuel source.
The upper surface of the zone of saturation, where the soil or rocks are permanently saturated with water.
A model of car rental where people rent cars for short periods of time, often by the hour.
A thin part of the Earth's atmosphere that absorbs almost all of the sun's harmful ultraviolet light.
When the timing of seasonal activities of interacting species (e.g., plants and pollinators) no longer synchronise due to climate change.
A voluntary method of environmental performance certification and labelling that is practised around the world.
The non-continuous nature of some renewable energy sources, like wind and solar, which are not available 24/7.
A non-binding action plan of the United Nations with regard to sustainable development, created at the 1992 Earth Summit.
An area of land maintained in permanent vegetation that helps to control air quality, soil quality, and water quality from agricultural runoff.
A usage-pricing model for disposing of municipal solid waste where users are charged a rate based on how much waste they present for collection.
The artificial process of applying controlled amounts of water to land to assist in the production of crops.
The challenge of moving people and goods from a transportation hub to a final destination in an efficient and sustainable manner.
A measure of how much the Earth's climate will cool or warm after a change in the climate system, for instance, a doubling of the carbon dioxide concentrations.
The ongoing trend of declines in the populations of amphibians worldwide, to which climate change is a contributing factor.

A design framework that seeks to create production techniques that are not just efficient but are essentially waste-free. All material inputs and outputs are seen as either technical or biological nutrients.
A policy mechanism designed to accelerate investment in renewable energy technologies by offering long-term contracts to renewable energy producers.
A body of citizens who are randomly selected to deliberate on an issue of public importance, such as climate change in Ireland.
A system that combines aquaculture (raising aquatic animals such as fish) with hydroponics (cultivating plants in water) in a symbiotic environment.
Water that has percolated through a solid and leached out some of the constituents, such as from a landfill.
Any single identifiable source of pollution from which pollutants are discharged, such as a pipe, ditch, ship or factory smokestack.
Pollution resulting from many diffuse sources, in direct contrast to point source pollution which results from a single source. E.g., agricultural runoff.

The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of one gram of a substance by one degree Celsius. Water has a very high specific heat capacity, allowing oceans to store vast amounts of heat.
An unplanned, unwanted, and uncontrolled fire in an area of combustible vegetation. Climate change is increasing their frequency and intensity.
A social and economic theory that advocates for the downscaling of production and consumption, contracting economies to a level that can be sustained by the planet.
The minimum level of electricity demand required over a period of 24 hours. It is the power needed to provide electricity to components that keep running at all times.
A field of academic research that aims to understand and manage the economy as a subsystem of the larger ecosystem of Earth.
An agricultural system that uses ecologically based pest controls and biological fertilizers derived largely from animal and plant wastes and nitrogen-fixing cover crops.
Commonly known as trash or garbage, this is waste consisting of everyday items that are discarded by the public.
The phenomenon that after supply increases, more of a good is consumed. E.g., building more roads can lead to more traffic.
The long-term storage of carbon in plants, soils, geologic formations, and the ocean.
The ability to anticipate, prepare for, and respond to hazardous events, trends, or disturbances related to climate.
A holistic approach to analysis that focuses on the way that a system's constituent parts interrelate and how systems work over time and within the context of larger systems.
The relationships between nations as they relate to the production, transportation, and consumption of energy resources.
The act of removing investments from companies involved in the extraction and combustion of fossil fuels.
A type of horticulture and a subset of hydroculture which involves growing plants, usually crops, without soil, by using mineral nutrient solutions in an aqueous solvent.
Discarded electronic devices and their parts.
An artificial channel for conveying water, typically in the form of a bridge across a valley or other gap.
The practice of designing streets to slow down or reduce motor-vehicle traffic to improve safety for pedestrians and cyclists and improve the local environment.
The pathway by which a chemical substance cycles the biotic and abiotic compartments of Earth.
A part of the large-scale ocean circulation that is driven by global density gradients created by surface heat and freshwater fluxes.
A term used in life-cycle assessment to describe the entire life of a product from its creation to its disposal.
The small-scale generation of heat and/or electric power by individuals, small businesses and communities to meet their own needs.
The principle that those who produce pollution should bear the costs of managing it to prevent damage to human health or the environment.
The continued capacity of soil to function as a vital living ecosystem that sustains plants, animals, and humans.
A regenerative system for the fashion industry, in which clothes are circulated for as long as their maximum value is retained, and then returned safely to the biosphere.
The relationship between how much water is used to generate and transmit energy, and how much energy it takes to collect, clean, move, store, and dispose of water.
A layer of vegetation planted over a waterproofing membrane on a roof.
Fast flowing, narrow, meandering air currents in the atmospheres of some planets, including Earth. Changes in the jet stream can lead to extreme weather.
A prolonged period of anomalously warm ocean temperatures in a particular region.
The ongoing acceptance of a company or industry's standard business practices and operating procedures by its employees, stakeholders and the general public.
The use of a heat engine or power station to generate electricity and useful heat at the same time.
The process of taking environmental, social and governance (ESG) considerations into account when making investment decisions in the financial sector.
The process in which the value of the biophysical environment is affected by a combination of human-induced processes acting upon the land.
The process of recovering fiber, yarn or fabric and reprocessing the textile material into useful products.
The saltiness or amount of salt dissolved in a body of water.
A low-cost, temporary approach to urban planning and design that aims to improve local neighbourhoods and city gathering places.
Instructions are fetched one by one from main memory, decoded, and then executed by the processor. This cycle repeats until the program is complete
A chip within the computer which controls the operation of all parts of the computer and decodes then executes program instructions
The part of the CPU responsible for arithmetic and logical operations
High speed memory built into the CPU. Instructions are copied to cache memory allowing them to be accessed more quickly and therefore increasing the speed of the CPU
A small area of memory within the CPU where data is stored temporarily to avoid the delay in copying to and from main memory
The design on which most computers are based. It defines several registers along with the fetch-execute cycle and how the CPU interacts with main memory
A register. It contains the address of the instruction currently being read from or written to main memory
A register. It contains the instruction which has just been copied from main memory
A register. It contains the address of the next instruction to be fetched from memory. It is updated each time a new instruction is fetched to contain the address of the next needed instruction
A register. Stores the result of the last operation
How many instruction cycles the CPU can deal with in a second. Measured in MHz or GHz. Faster is better
The larger the amount of cache the CPU has the more instructions it can store without having to transfer to main memory and therefore the faster it will perform

Some CPUs have more than one core, each containing its own ALU and registers and therefore capable of carrying out instructions independently. The more cores, the more instructions the CPU can process at once and therefore the faster it performs

Specialist hardware and software build into a device with a single dedicated purpose. They can be found within appliances such as washing machines, dishwashers, but could also be sensors for measurement of, for example, pH, sound levels, light intensity, etc
Also known as memory. Holds the data, programs and instructions currently in use
Small portion of very fast memory that stores copies of data from frequently used locations in the primary storage. Faster than RAM or ROM
Random Access Memory. Stores programs and data before they are processed by the CPU. Read/write memory, meaning the contents can be changed. The contents are lost when the computer is turned off
Read Only Memory. Data can be retrieved but not changed and the contents are not lost when the computer is turned off. Used to store programs for embedded system
Data stored in volatile memory is lost when the computer is turned off
Data stored in non-volatile memory is not lost when the computer is turned off
Space on the computer's hard drive used as main memory (RAM). Virtual memory is slower than main memory
A type of secondary storage which stores data on a spinning plastic or metal disk. Data is read from and written to the disk using a laser
A type of secondary storage which uses magnetic fields to store data. A read/write head reads and writes data from the media
A type of secondary storage which uses flash memory to store data. They have no moving parts and are much faster than optical or magnetic storage

A magnetic storage drive which can store large amounts of data and is often the main method of secondary storage in personal computers. The drive contains a number of internal disks and a read/write head used to read and write data
A high capacity optical storage disk commonly used for video storage. A range of capacities are available up to 17GB
An optical storage disk often used to store music. Capacity is usually around 800mb

A solid state storage drive which carries out the function of a traditional HDD. They are much faster than HDDs and less easy to damage as they have no moving parts. They are also more expensive and usually lower capacity
The smallest unit of storage, containing a binary 1 or 0
4 bits (half a byte)
8 bits
1000 bytes
A number system used by computers. It contains only two symbols, 0 and 1 and is also known as base 2
The number system most often used by people. It uses the digits 0 to 9 and is also known as base 10 or decimal
A number greater than 0
A number less than 0
A whole number without a decimal point or fraction. E.g. 1, 100 or 88122
This happens when not enough space has been allocated to store the results of a calculation. For example, if one byte has been allocated but the result is 9 bits long
A number system used by computers. It contains only two symbols, 0 and 1 and is also known as base 2
A process used to preform maths on binary numbers. It involves moving all the digits to the left or right
The furthest left digit in a string of binary numbers, its position means it has the highest value
The furthest right digit in a string of binary numbers, its position means it has the lowest value
A single symbol, for example a letter, number or punctuation mark
A system for representing characters in binary, each character is assigned a unique binary number
American Standard Code for Information Interchange. A 7 bit character set used to represent characters
A much larger character set created to overcome the limited number of characters available in ASCII. It includes many different language characters as well as other symbols such emojis
Short for Picture Element. Pictures on a computer are divided into a grid, with each square in the grid being one pixel which can be a single colour
Additional data about a file such as when it was created or who created it. Commonly used with photos to store things like the make of camera or location the photo was taken

The number of samples taken in one second. This is measured in hertz (Hz), 1Hz is one sample per second. The higher the sample rate, the more samples per second and therefore the higher the quality of the file
The number of bits available for each sample. The higher the bit depth, the more bits available and therefore the better the quality
A continuously varying signal, usually represented as a curved line. Opposite of digital, which, in computing, has only two values (1 and 0). Examples include sound or temperature recordings
A way of reducing the size of a file. It is often used with photos, music and video files

A compression method which reduces the file size by removing certain data. The original file cannot be restored from the compressed version but the file is reduced by more than with lossless compression
A compression method which reduces the file size without losing any data. The original file can be restored from the compressed version, but the file size is not reduced by as much
Two or more computers connected together for the purposes of sharing data or resources
A network which covers a small geographic area such as a single building
A network which covers a large geographic area
A network setup where resources or processing are carried out by a central computer (called a server) with other devices (called clients) accessing resources via the network
A network setup where all computers have an equal status and function as both client and server
Uses a wireless radio to allow devices to connect wirelessly to an existing network
A device which connects two or more different networks together allowing them to communicate with one another
A device which provides computers and other devices with a wired connection to a network

A component within a computer or other device which allow it to connect to a network. The card provides the physical connection to the network and controls the sending and receiving of data between the computer and the network. It may be built into the computer motherboard or a separate expansion card
The physical connection which carries data between network devices. This could be a cable or wireless signals depending on the network
A system which links a URL or other human readable name with an IP address
The storing of files or other data on a server. The server storing the data is called the host
A term for accessing storage or other resources remotely across The Internet
A server which hosts web sites and pages for users to access, usually via The Internet
The way in which computers and other network devices are connected together
A network topology where all devices connect back to a single central point. All communications travel via the central point
A network topology where all devices are connected to each other rather than a central point
The amount of data which can be transferred via a network in any given time. More bandwidth allows more data to travel across the network at the same time resulting in faster transfer speeds
A global network connecting millions of computers and other devices
Uniform Resource Locator. A human readable name given to websites and other Internet resources. DNS is used to translate the URL into the IP of the web server
A computer or other device which accesses data from a central server
A physical copper cable used to connect devices on a network. The term also refers to the protocols and standards used to control how data is sent and received on the cable
A technology which uses wireless signals to connect network devices
A short range wireless networking technology. It has relatively low range and speeds and is most often used for peripheral devices such as mice or headsets
The process of converting data so that it cannot be easily read or understood without first being decrypted. It is often used to keep important data secure when sharing it over a network
Stands for Internet Protocol Address. A unique address assigned to every computer on a network
Internet Protocol Version 4. Devices are assigned addresses made up of four numbers separated by dots, e.g. 232.112.11.1 each number can be between 0 and 255

Internet Protocol Version 6. Designed in response to the limited number of addresses in IPv4. Devices are assigned an address made of eight groups of hexadecimal characters such as FE80:CD00:0000:0CDE:1257:0000:211E:729C
Media Access Control Address. A 12 digit hexadecimal number assigned to a network interface card. Each card has its own unique MAC addressed assigned when the card is made

An agreed way of doing something allowing different people and organisations to make products and services which work together. There are many standards for networking and communications. Examples: HTML, IP, Bluetooth, GSM, 4G, 5G
An agreed set of rules for how network communications should take place
Transfer Control Protocol / Internet Protocol. A group of standards which control how data is sent and received over networks including the Internet
Hypertext Transfer Protocol. A standard for transferring web pages between a client and web server. It is based around the idea that clients send a request which the server responds to
Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure. A version of the HTTP standard with security added. Commonly used for accessing secure websites such as online banking
File Transfer Protocol. A standard for file transfer over networks
Post Office Protocol. A standard used by email clients to retrieve emails from an email server

Internet Message Access Protocol. A standard used by email clients to access emails stored on an email server. It has the advantage over POP of allowing emails to be stored and organised on the mail server
Simple Message Transfer Protocol. A standard used for the sending of emails over networks and The Internet

A term for any software which is designed with malicious intent. Malware may damage the computer, monitor user activity and files or delete or damage data. There are many different types of malware which behave in different ways

Attempting to gain access to computer systems by targeting the people using the system instead of using technical measures to attack the system itself. People are often the weakest security point in a computer system and examples such as watching someone enter their password or pretending to be their boss and telling them to do something urgently aim to take advantage of this fact

Attempting to trick someone in to revealing information such as their password, financial, or other private information by pretending to be someone else. Phishing usually takes place by email, and involves sending an email which pretends to have come from the user's bank or other trusted organisation or person

Attempting to guess a code or password by trying every possible solution until the correct one is found. The attack may work through a list of common passwords or dictionary words, or simply start with a code of 0000, followed by 0001 etc

Attempting to send more traffic or data to a computer system than it is able to handle. If successful, this results in parts of the system, or even the whole system, being unable to process the data is receiving and failing

Attempting to access data whilst it is being transferred between devices, usually over a network. The victim usually has no idea that their data has been stolen, and the attacker may access usernames and passwords or whole files

Entering SQL code into a data input field on a web site or application. If the system is not correctly coded, and uses a SQL database, the code could be run directly on the database, allowing the attacker to access, change or delete the entire database

An authorised hacking attempt where a person or company attempts to hack into a system or network and then reports their finding to the system's owner. This allows security flaws to be fixed before real hackers can take advantage of them
Software which attempts to detect, prevent and remove malware on a computer system. Anti-Virus software is a common example of antimalware software

A network security device which checks traffic passing through it against a set of rules, only traffic which meets the rules is allowed through. This prevents traffic from unauthorised devices or using unauthorised protocols from passing through

Controlling which aspects of a system or network users can access. Users are allowed access only to the parts of the system the need, preventing them from accidentally or deliberately damaging sensitive parts of the system or accessing sensitive data
A secret word or phrase, usually provided alongside a username, to control access to a system or network. Only someone who knows the correct password can access the system

Securing the physical components of a system or network. This could be as simple as locking a portable computer to a desk or advanced as storing servers in a reinforced building with multiple locked doors
Controls the operation of all aspects of the computer and provides an interface by which a user can interact with the computer. Examples: Microsoft Windows, MacOS, UNIX, Android, iOS

A part of the operating system or other software which allows the user to interact with and control it. They usually comprise of a graphical component which the user can see on a monitor or other display hardware, and way for the user to interact with the system, either by typing commands, or clicking items with a mouse or touchscreen
The function of the Operating System which manages the computer's memory, controlling how the memory is used and which applications can access it
The ability for an operating system to run more than one task or application at the same time
The ability of an operating system to control and manage hardware devices such as printers, mice or speakers which are connected to the computer

Computer code which provides instructions for how the operating system should interact with a specific piece of hardware. Device drivers are specific to the operating system and piece of hardware for which they were designed

A function of the operating system which manages user accounts. In many cases, multiple user accounts can exist with their own username, password and access rights allowing more than one person to use the same computer
A function of the operating system which manages files and folders stored on either the computer's internal storage, or external storage devices such as a USB Stick

A function of the operating system which manages the access that different users and applications have to the system. It allows different user accounts or applications to be granted access to different parts of the system

Software which encrypts data. The encryption process turns the data into code which is only readable with the correct key. This is designed to keep the data secure and prevent it being read by those who should not have access to it
Software which reorders files stored on a hard disk so that they run in a sensible order to improve performance and efficiency
Software which compresses data so that it takes up less storage space
The idea of right and wrong by which people should behave. This is not the same as what is legal or illegal, but the idea of always doing the right thing
A set of rules which lay out behaviours which are not allowed and the punishments for breaking these rules. Laws vary from country to country, with new laws being made and existing ones being updated

A set of behaviours and expectations which people accept as being normal and expected within their daily lives. These are not enforced by any laws, and don't always have to do with right and wrong, but are how people expect things should be. An example might be colouring a delete button red, or ordering items starting at the top left of the screen
Matters relating to the natural world around us and making sure we take good care of things like animals, the atmosphere and the planet as a whole
The expectation that certain information is kept secret. Usually this relates to personal information such as someone's address or medical history which they would not want to be shared

A law in the EU which governs the processing of personal data. It outlines the requirements for organisations who handle data and the rights of those who provide the data. GPDR(General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR):)

The right for an organisation or user to use a piece of computer software. The license is an agreement between the person or organisation who made the software and those using it and lays out any rules or restrictions associated with use. The user may have to pay either a one time or yearly fee for the license
Software where the code is made available to the public to view or edit as they wish. Open source software is usually free for anyone to use
Software where the source code is owned by a person or organisation and is not available to the public
The process of thinking about a problem using computational means in order to create a solution which a computer can implement
The process of removing irrelevant or unnecessary information from the problem in order to better understand the basic parts of it
The process of breaking a problem down into smaller parts to make it easier to solve
The process of working out the individual steps needed to solve a problem in order to produce an algorithmic solution
A sequence of logical instructions to carry out a particular task
A diagram which shows in graphical format the steps needed to solve a problem. There are several different types of structure diagram and a flow chart is one example
A way of writing out algorithms or other computer programs in a way which sits somewhere between full sentences and computer code
A way of using pictures and shapes to represent the steps needed to solve a problem or that a program will take
A language which can be understood by computers to produce computer software
Something wrong in computer code which causes it either to not run at all or to produce an incorrect output
Finding a value or piece of information within a set of data

A way of searching an ordered list by looking at the middle item in the list, then looking at either the items above or below depending on if the required value is higher or lower. This process repeats until the value is found
A way of searching through a list items, checking them one at a time until the required value is found
A way of placing information into a certain order, such as alphabetically or by number
A way or sorting a list by comparing the items in a list, two at a time, and changing the order if needed. The process repeats until the list is in the correct order

This recursive algorithm works by picking an element as a pivot and rearranging the array so that all elements less than the pivot come before it, and all elements greater than the pivot come after it. It then recursively applies this partitioning process to the sub-arrays of smaller and larger elements until the entire array is sorted

This sorting method repeatedly finds the minimum element from the unsorted part of the array and places it at the beginning of the sorted part. The algorithm iterates through the array, selecting the smallest remaining element and swapping it into its correct sorted position until the entire array is sorted
A way of sorting a list by working through the items one at a time and placing them in the correct position in the list
Measures how the execution time of an algorithm grows as the input size increases. It's often expressed using Big O notation to describe the upper bound of the growth rate
Measures the amount of memory (storage space) an algorithm uses as a function of the input size. Similar to time complexity, it's often described using Big O notation

A mathematical notation used to describe the limiting behavior of a function when the argument tends towards a particular value or infinity. In algorithm analysis, it describes the worst-case scenario for time or space complexity
The maximum amount of time or space an algorithm will take for any input of a given size. This provides an upper bound on the algorithm's resource usage. We are more focused on time rather than space

The average amount of time or space an algorithm takes, considering all possible inputs of a given size and assuming a certain distribution of those inputs. This is often harder to calculate than worst-case complexity
A named value in which data can be stored by a computer program. The data can be changed as the program runs
A named value which is accessed by a computer program but is fixed and cannot be changed
Operators compare or modify values in computer code. Examples include + < and NOT
Data or information which is put into the program. This could be entered via a user, or taken from a sensor
Data or information which the program produces. This could be shown on a screen, sent to a printer, or saved to a file
The process of placing a value in to a variable
Following through a set of steps in a particular order
Taking different paths through the code depending on a condition
Repeating a set of steps several times
Using a counter to loop through one or more lines of code until they have been run a certain number of times
Using a loop to repeat one or more lines of code until a certain condition is met
An operator which uses maths to modify numbers such as +
An operator which uses a logical criteria to compare two values such as < or AND
A whole number without a decimal point or fraction. E.g. 1, 100 or 88122
A number which may include a decimal point such as 11.2
A value which can be only TRUE or FALSE
A single symbol, for example a letter, number or punctuation mark
A number of characters together, usually to form a word or sentence
The process of forcing a value into a certain format, for example forcing a telephone number to be stored as a string and not an integer
A broad term for a number of ways to change or modify strings
The process of joining two or more strings together
The process of splitting a string into two or more parts
Ways in which computer code can interact with files on the computer's disk, such as opening them or writing data to them
A single row or related information in a database table
A group of records and fields stored together in a database
A part of a record in the database which stores specific information such as a name or address
Structured Query Language. A programming language designed to be used with databases
A set of data items stored together with a single name and accessed by a program
A smaller part of the program which performs a specific task
A sub program which performs a specific tasks and always returns a specific value when run
A sub program which performs a specific task but does not always return a value

A number generated by computer at random. Essential in LC Comp Science , primarily because they introduce unpredictability and variability, which are essential for various applications, e.g. computer games, computer security, simulations and modelling
Designing and building computer code with the ability to keep it secure, easy to maintain and robust as a priority
A security mechanism which requires a password, code, fingerprint or other factor to gain access to all or part of a system
The process of comparing data entered into the program to a set of rules to ensure it is valid and will not damage the system before processing it
The ability to keep code updated, fix bugs and add new features easily
An agreed way of naming parts of the program such as variables or sub programs such that they are easy to read and their purpose is clear
Inserting spaces at the start of a line or lines of code so to group them together and make the code easier to read
Lines which do not form part of the code and are not executed but instead provide notes and explanations to those looking at the code
The process of trialling a program in order to ensure it performs as expected
Focuses on testing individual, isolated parts of the code (units) to ensure they function correctly in isolation. It verifies that each component performs as designed
Involves examining the internal structure and code of the software to design test cases. The tester has knowledge of the implementation details
Tests the software without knowledge of its internal structure, focusing on the inputs and outputs. The tester evaluates functionality from an end-user perspective
Testing which is carried out whilst the program is being developed
Testing which is carried out at the end of development just before the code is released
An error which breaks the rules of the programming language and stops the code from running
An error which produces an unexpected output even though the code still runs
Data which the program should accept without error
Data at the extremes of what the program should accept without error
Data of the correct type, but not valid for the program and which should be rejected
Data which is the wrong type and should be rejected
Has two inputs and outputs 1 only if both are 1
Has two inputs, if both are 1 then outputs 1, otherwise outputs 0
Has a single input and outputs the opposite of that input
Opposite of AND, it's true(1) only if at least one of its inputs is false
Opposite of OR, It's true(1) only if both of its inputs are false
It's true only if two inputs are different
A table which shows the possible input and output values for a logic gate
An operator such as AND, OR or NOT which performs a logical function on the input
A diagram showing one or more logic gates together
A language which can be understood by computers to produce computer software
A programming language which is close to English in the commands used making it easier to learn and understand
A programming language closer to machine code, using less English like commands making it harder to understand
A piece of software which converts programming language into machine code which the computer can understand and execute
A translator which converts code in one go. Example languages that are compiled: C, C++
A translator which converts code line by line. Example languages that are interpreted: Python, JavaScript, Ruby

A piece of software used by developers to write computer code. They often contain features such as translators and syntax highlighters to make it easier to write code. Thonny and Visual Studio are examples of IDEs
A piece of software used to write computer code
Tools to help locate and resolve errors in code
A tool which allows code to run on a system for which it was not designed. For example, running a mobile phone app on a desktop computer
Extremely large datasets that require specialized tools for analysis
Discovering patterns and insights from large datasets
Using data to forecast future trends and outcomes
Algorithms that enable computers to learn from data without explicit programming
Extract, Transform, Load: the processing of collecting and preparing data for analysis
The process of correcting or removing inaccurate data
A structured collection of data organized for efficient access and management
Tools and processes for analyzing data to inform business decisions
Representing data graphically to understand trends and patterns
A blueprint or logical structure of a database
Software that allows users to create, manage, and query databases. Examples: Oracle, MySQL, Microsoft SQLServer
A unique identifier for each row in a database table
A field in one table that references the primary key in another table, establishing a relationship
Entity Relationship Diagram, used to describe key entities and relationships between them
Organizes data into tables with rows and columns, linked by relationships. Examples are MySQL, SQL Server, Oracle, PostgreSQL
Structured Query Language
Non-relational databases that handle unstructured or semi-structured data. Examples are Firebase, MongoDB, DynamoDB, Neo4J
Personal Protective Equipment, such as a hard hat, steel-toed boots, high-vis vest, gloves, and safety glasses.
A written document outlining how a company manages health and safety in the workplace, identifying hazards and assessing risks.
The process of identifying potential hazards and analyzing what could happen if a hazard occurs.
The transporting or supporting of a load by hand or bodily force. It is a common cause of workplace injuries.
A one-day safety awareness programme for construction workers, required for anyone working on a construction site.
A system (e.g., green, yellow, red tags) used to indicate the safety status of scaffolding. Green means it is safe to use.
Health and Safety Authority. The state agency in Ireland responsible for workplace health and safety.
Anything with the potential to cause harm, such as trailing cables, working at height, or asbestos.
An informal safety meeting, usually held on-site, that focuses on a specific job-related safety topic.
Immediate assistance given to any person suffering a sudden illness or injury.
The process of collecting information about a site's ground conditions to determine its suitability for a proposed construction project.
A pit dug on-site to examine the soil profile and determine the depth of the water table.
A test to determine the absorption rate of soil for a septic tank drain field or soakaway.
Formal permission from a local authority for the erection or alteration of buildings or other structures.
A set of legal requirements for the design and construction of new buildings, extensions, and material alterations to ensure health, safety, and welfare.
A drawing showing the layout of a property or group of properties, including boundaries, buildings, and access routes.
The height of a point on land in relation to mean sea level. Used as a reference point for levelling.
A formal process to predict the environmental consequences of a proposed development before it is carried out.
The process of transferring the building design from drawings onto the ground, marking out the position of foundations and walls.
Timber frames erected clear of the foundation trenches, onto which the building lines are transferred and held.
The part of the structure that transmits the building's load to the supporting ground.
A continuous strip of concrete that supports load-bearing walls.
A large slab of concrete covering the entire footprint of a building, used on soft or unstable ground.
Long columns of concrete, steel, or timber driven into the ground to transfer loads to a deeper, more stable soil layer.
An isolated concrete pad used to support a single point load, such as a column.
The wall built from the top of the foundation up to the ground floor level (DPC level).
A layer of broken stones or rubble compacted to provide a solid base for a ground floor slab.
A thin layer of fine material, like sand or weak concrete, laid over hardcore to create a smooth, level surface.
A radioactive gas that comes from the ground and can accumulate in buildings, posing a health risk.
'A membrane installed in the floor construction to prevent radon gas from entering the building.'
Damp Proof Course. An impermeable layer built into a wall to prevent rising damp.
Damp Proof Membrane. A sheet of impermeable material, like polythene, laid under a concrete floor to prevent moisture from the ground rising into the building.
A floor consisting of a concrete slab cast directly onto a hardcore base.
A floor consisting of timber joists supported by sleeper walls, creating a void underneath.
Small walls built on top of the foundations to provide intermediate support for the joists in a suspended timber floor.
Bricks with small openings built into the rising walls of a suspended floor to ensure adequate sub-floor ventilation.
A wall constructed of two separate leaves (inner and outer) with a continuous air gap (cavity) in between.
The internal skin of a cavity wall, usually built from concrete blocks and is load-bearing.
The external skin of a cavity wall, which protects the structure from weather. Usually made of brick or rendered block.
Metal strips (often stainless steel) used to tie the inner and outer leaves of a cavity wall together, providing stability.
Small openings left in the mortar joints of the outer leaf, just above the DPC and lintels, to allow trapped moisture to escape.
A horizontal beam of concrete or steel placed above an opening (like a door or window) to support the load above it.
The internal sides of a window or door opening.
The vertical sides of a door or window frame.
The horizontal component at the bottom of a window opening, designed to shed water away from the wall.
A method of construction where the structural frame is made of timber panels, which are then clad with brick, block, or render.
A board or panel material, like plywood or OSB, fastened to the outside of a timber frame to provide structural rigidity.
A membrane fixed to the outside of the timber frame sheathing. It is waterproof but allows water vapour to escape.
A membrane placed on the warm side of the insulation in a timber frame wall to prevent moisture vapour from entering the structure and causing condensation.
A roof that slopes downwards, typically in two parts from a central ridge.
A roof that is nearly level, with a very slight slope (fall) to allow rainwater to drain.
A prefabricated structural framework of timbers designed to bridge the space above a room and provide support for a roof.
The most common type of roof truss, shaped like a 'W'.
A truss with a central vertical post, used for shorter spans.
An inclined timber member that forms the main structure of a pitched roof.
The horizontal timber at the apex of a pitched roof to which the tops of the rafters are fixed.
A horizontal beam that provides intermediate support for the rafters.
A horizontal timber that forms the 'floor' of the attic and the 'ceiling' of the room below. It also ties the feet of the rafters together.
The vertical board fixed to the ends of the rafters, to which the guttering is attached.
The board that encloses the underside of the roof overhang.
A board fixed to the gable end of a roof to protect the projecting timbers.
A waterproof, breathable membrane laid over the rafters before the battens, acting as a secondary barrier against wind and rain.
Horizontal timber strips fixed to the rafters, on top of the underlay, to which the roof tiles or slates are attached.
Vertical timber strips fixed directly to the rafters, underneath the main battens, to create a ventilation channel in a warm roof design.
A roof with four sloping sides, eliminating the need for gables.
A roof with two sloping sides that meet at a ridge, with a triangular wall (gable) at each end.
Sheet metal (usually lead, copper, or zinc) used to weatherproof junctions, such as where a roof meets a chimney or wall.
The internal angle formed by the intersection of two sloping roof surfaces.
Timber from coniferous trees (cone-bearing), which are generally fast-growing and have needles. e.g., Scots Pine, Spruce.
Timber from broad-leaved, deciduous trees, which are generally slow-growing. e.g., Oak, Ash, Teak.
The controlled process of drying timber to reduce its moisture content, making it more stable and resistant to decay.
A natural method of drying timber by stacking it outdoors, protected from rain, allowing air to circulate freely.
A rapid method of drying timber in a controlled chamber (kiln) where temperature, humidity, and air circulation are regulated.
The weight of water in a piece of wood, expressed as a percentage of the oven-dry weight of the wood.
The process of sawing a felled log into usable timber sections.
The simplest method of conversion, where the log is cut into parallel planks. It is quick but can lead to cupping.
A method of conversion where the log is first cut into quarters and then sawn radially. It produces stable boards with an attractive grain but is more wasteful.
A defect in timber caused by the base of a branch that was embedded in the tree trunk.
A defect in timber where the wood fibres separate along the grain, often caused by stress in the tree during growth.
A distortion in timber where the board turns or bends from its original shape as it dries.
The treatment of timber with chemicals to protect it from fungal decay and insect attack.
A preservation method where timber is placed in a vacuum cylinder, and preservative is forced into the wood under pressure.
A manufactured board made by gluing together thin layers (veneers) of wood, with the grain of each layer at right angles to the next.
A manufactured board made from fine wood fibres mixed with wax and resin, formed into panels by applying high temperature and pressure.
A manufactured board made from wood chips, sawmill shavings, or even sawdust, mixed with a synthetic resin and pressed.
A manufactured board made from compressed layers of wood strands (flakes) in specific orientations.
A composite material composed of fine and coarse aggregate bonded together with a fluid cement that hardens over time.
Granular material such as sand, gravel, or crushed stone used with a cement to form concrete.
A binder, a substance used for construction that sets, hardens, and adheres to other materials to bind them together. Most common type is Portland Cement.
The chemical reaction between cement and water that causes concrete to set and harden.
The process of maintaining adequate moisture and temperature in concrete for a period of time after it has been placed, to ensure proper hydration.
The ease with which fresh concrete can be mixed, placed, compacted, and finished without segregation.
An on-site test to measure the consistency and workability of fresh concrete.
A lab test to determine the compressive strength of hardened concrete, performed on cubes of concrete after 7 and 28 days of curing.
Concrete in which steel reinforcement (rebar) is embedded to resist tensile forces.
Concrete in which internal stresses are introduced before external loads are applied, to counteract the tensile stresses the concrete will be subjected to in service.
A thin layer of material, usually sand and cement, laid on top of a concrete slab to provide a smooth, level finish.
Metals that contain iron. They are known for their strength and durability but are prone to rust. e.g., Mild Steel, Cast Iron.
Metals that do not contain iron. They are more resistant to corrosion than ferrous metals. e.g., Aluminium, Copper, Lead, Zinc.
A metal made by combining two or more metallic elements, especially to give greater strength or resistance to corrosion. e.g., Brass (Copper & Zinc), Stainless Steel (Steel & Chromium).
A common ferrous metal used for structural sections (RSJs), reinforcement bars, and lintels due to its strength and low cost.
The process of applying a protective zinc coating to steel or iron to prevent rusting.
A lightweight, corrosion-resistant, non-ferrous metal commonly used for window frames and cladding.
A ductile, corrosion-resistant, non-ferrous metal with excellent thermal and electrical conductivity, used for plumbing pipes and electrical wiring.
A soft, dense, malleable, non-ferrous metal used for roof flashings due to its durability and ease of forming.
A wide range of synthetic or semi-synthetic materials that use polymers as a main ingredient.
Plastics that can be repeatedly softened by heating and hardened by cooling. They are recyclable. e.g., PVC, Polythene.
Plastics that, once 'set' after initial heating, cannot be softened or remoulded. They are not recyclable. e.g., Bakelite (electrical fittings), Urea-Formaldehyde (adhesives).
A common thermoplastic used for window frames, soil and waste pipes, and electrical cable insulation.
A thermoplastic used for damp-proof membranes (DPM), temporary weather protection, and water pipes.
A window that is attached to its frame by one or more hinges at the side, opening inwards or outwards.
A window made of one or more movable panels, or 'sashes', that slide vertically.
The fixed, non-moving part of a window that holds the sash or casement.
The glass panes in a window or door.
A window unit consisting of two panes of glass separated by a sealed air or gas-filled gap to provide thermal and acoustic insulation.
Glass with a microscopic metallic coating that reflects thermal radiation, keeping heat in during winter and out during summer.
An inert gas often used to fill the gap in double or triple glazed units to improve thermal insulation.
A measure of the rate of heat loss through a material. The lower the U-value, the better the insulation.
A simple door made of vertical boards (ledges) held together by horizontal battens (ledges) and a diagonal brace.
Ledged and Braced Door
A door constructed with a frame of stiles (vertical members) and rails (horizontal members), with the spaces filled by thinner panels.
An internal door with a lightweight core (often a honeycomb of cardboard), used where sound insulation is not a priority.
A door with a core of solid wood, chipboard or other composite material, providing better insulation and fire resistance.
A set of steps leading from one floor of a building to another.
A staircase that does not change direction.
A staircase that makes a 90-degree or 180-degree turn, usually at a landing.
The horizontal part of a step that you walk on.
The vertical part of a step.
The inclined board at the side of a staircase that supports the treads and risers.
The main post at the top, bottom, or at a turn in a staircase that supports the handrail.
The rail that is followed by the hand for support when using a staircase.
The vertical posts that support the handrail.
The complete assembly of handrail, balusters, and newel posts.
The horizontal distance from the front to the back of a tread.
The vertical distance from the top of one tread to the top of the next.
The angle of inclination of the staircase.
The minimum clear vertical height from the pitch line of the stairs to the ceiling or structure above.
The process of applying a plaster mix to walls and ceilings to create a smooth, hard surface.
The first coat in external plastering (rendering), a wet mix of cement, sand and water thrown onto the wall to provide a key for the next coat.
The first coat of plaster in a three-coat system, which is scratched to provide a key for the next coat.
The second coat of plaster, applied to level the surface.
The final, thin coat of plaster that provides a smooth surface for decorating.
A panel made of gypsum plaster pressed between two thick sheets of paper, used to make interior walls and ceilings.
The process of fixing plasterboard to walls, either by dabs of adhesive or onto a timber framework, as an alternative to wet plastering.
A board running along the bottom of an interior wall, covering the joint between the wall surface and the floor.
A moulded frame around a doorway or window.
Water supplied directly to a property by a local water authority.
The pipe that carries mains water from the stopcock outside the building up to the cold water storage tank.
A plumbing system where all cold water taps are supplied directly from the rising main at mains pressure.
A plumbing system where only the kitchen sink cold tap is supplied directly from the rising main. All other taps are fed from a cold water storage tank in the attic.
A tank, usually in the attic, that stores cold water to supply the hot water cylinder and cold taps (in an indirect system).
An insulated tank used to store hot water, heated either by an electric immersion heater or by the central heating boiler.
An electric heating element that is inserted into the hot water cylinder to heat the water.
A warm cupboard, typically containing the hot water cylinder, used for storing linen.
A large diameter pipe that carries waste from toilets to the underground drainage system.
A smaller diameter pipe that carries 'grey water' from sinks, baths, and showers.
A U-shaped section of pipe located under sinks and toilets, which holds water to prevent foul-smelling gases from the drainage system entering the house.
A pipe that extends from the soil pipe up to above roof level, allowing gases to escape and preventing a vacuum from forming in the drainage system.
A system that heats a whole building from one source, such as a boiler.
The appliance that burns fuel (e.g., gas, oil) to heat water for the central heating system and domestic hot water.
A high-efficiency boiler that captures and reuses heat from the flue gases that would otherwise escape into the atmosphere.
A heat exchanger that transfers thermal energy from the hot water circulating through it to the air in a room.
A self-regulating valve fitted to a radiator that controls the temperature of a room by changing the flow of hot water to the radiator.
A device that senses the air temperature in a room and switches the heating on or off to maintain a pre-set temperature.
A device that allows the user to set times for when the central heating and hot water should turn on and off.
The main control centre for a building's electrical supply, containing the main switch, circuit breakers, and RCDs.
An automatic safety switch that 'trips' (cuts the power) if it detects an overload or short circuit.
A life-saving device that quickly breaks an electric circuit to prevent serious harm from an ongoing electric shock.
A wiring method where sockets are connected in a loop, starting and finishing at the consumer unit. Used for general purpose sockets.
A wiring method where a single cable runs from the consumer unit to the last socket or appliance on the circuit. Used for high-power appliances like cookers.
Connecting the metal casing of an electrical appliance to the ground via an earth wire, providing a safe path for current to flow away in the event of a fault.
A certificate that rates the energy efficiency of a building on a scale from A (most efficient) to G (least efficient).
A rigorous, voluntary standard for energy efficiency in a building, which reduces the building's ecological footprint. It results in ultra-low energy buildings.
The resistance of a building's envelope to inward or outward air leakage.
A test to measure the airtightness of a building by mounting a powerful fan in an external doorway to pressurise or depressurise the building.
A point in the building envelope (e.g., at a window reveal or floor/wall junction) where heat is transferred more easily, creating a 'cold bridge' and reducing insulation effectiveness.
A measure of the rate of heat loss through a building element (wall, roof, floor). The lower the U-value, the better the insulator.
The increase in temperature in a space, object, or structure that results from solar radiation.
A system that provides fresh, filtered air into a building while retaining most of the energy that has already been used in heating the building.
The reuse of wastewater from showers, baths, and washing machines for non-potable uses like toilet flushing and irrigation.
The collection and storage of rain for reuse on-site, rather than allowing it to run off.
A roof of a building that is partially or completely covered with vegetation and a growing medium, planted over a waterproofing membrane.
A 2D drawing showing a view of a building from above, as if a horizontal slice has been taken through it.
A 2D drawing showing one face (or side) of a building.
A 2D drawing showing a view of a building as if it has been cut through vertically, revealing the internal structure and construction details.
The ratio of the size of an object on a drawing to its size in reality (e.g., 1:100 means 1 unit on the drawing represents 100 units in reality).
The use of computers to create, modify, analyze, or optimize a design.
A method of 3D representation on a 2D surface where all vertical lines are drawn vertically, and all horizontal lines are drawn at 30 degrees to the horizontal.
A 3D drawing that creates a realistic impression of depth. Lines appear to converge at vanishing points.
A graphic convention used in section drawings to represent different materials (e.g., diagonal lines for concrete, wavy lines for insulation).
A layer of sand/cement mix laid on top of a concrete floor slab to provide a smooth, level finish.
A floor finish, like laminate or engineered wood, that is not fixed to the subfloor but rests on an underlay.
The lower edge of a roof that overhangs the face of a wall.
The edge of a roof over a gable wall.
A low protective wall along the edge of a roof, balcony, or bridge.
A cap or covering on top of a wall (like a parapet wall) to shed water.
A window that projects vertically from a sloping roof.
Concentric rings visible in a cross-section of a tree trunk, each ring representing one year's growth.
Ribbon-like tissues that extend radially from the pith to the bark, for storing and transporting food.
The decay of timber caused by fungi, which requires moisture, oxygen, and food (the wood itself). e.g., Dry Rot, Wet Rot.
Damage to timber caused by wood-boring insects, such as woodworm or termites.
The process of filling the joints between bricks or blocks with mortar.
A type of external plaster, usually a mix of cement, sand, and water, applied to external walls.
An external wall finish where small pebbles are thrown onto a fresh coat of render.
A valve for stopping the flow of water in a pipe. The main one is usually located where the water supply enters the property.
A valve that controls the refilling of a water tank (like a toilet cistern or attic tank), operated by a float.
A circuit that supplies power to the light fittings in a building.
A safety device consisting of a strip of wire that melts and breaks an electric circuit if the current exceeds a safe level.
The capacity of soil to support the loads applied to the ground.
The sudden sinking or gradual downward settling of the ground's surface with little or no horizontal motion.
The upward movement of the ground, often caused by the expansion of clay soils when they get wet.
A workable paste made of cement, sand, and water (and sometimes lime) used to bind building blocks together and fill the gaps between them.
A brick bonding pattern where courses of headers (end of brick) and stretchers (side of brick) alternate.
A brick bonding pattern where headers and stretchers alternate within each course.
The most common brick bonding pattern for cavity walls, consisting entirely of stretchers.
The vertical mortar joints between bricks in a wall.
A white, crystalline deposit of salts that can form on the surface of brick, concrete, or stone when water evaporates from it.
An older term for roofing underlay, often a bitumen-based felt.
A horizontal timber that connects two opposing rafters at a point above the wall plate, stiffening the roof structure.
A timber beam laid horizontally on top of a wall to provide a seating and fixing for the rafters or joists.
A small, controllable vent integrated into a window frame to provide background ventilation without opening the window.
The frame that is fixed into a wall opening, to which the door is hinged.
A strip of wood against which the door closes, fixed to the door frame.
The front edge of a tread that projects over the riser below.
Material used to reduce the rate of heat transfer.
Insulation boards made from materials like Polystyrene (EPS, XPS) or Polyisocyanurate (PIR), offering good thermal resistance for a given thickness.
Insulation made from mineral wool (rock or glass) or natural fibres (sheep's wool), often supplied in rolls or batts.
The total energy consumed by all of the processes associated with the production of a building, from the mining and processing of natural resources to manufacturing, transport and product delivery.

A technique to assess the environmental impacts associated with all the stages of a product's life from raw material extraction through materials processing, manufacture, distribution, use, repair and maintenance, and disposal or recycling.
Technical Guidance Document. Documents issued by the government that provide guidance on how to comply with the Building Regulations.
Building Regulation concerning the structural strength and stability of a building.
Building Regulation concerning safety measures to prevent and control the spread of fire.
