column4: Building Regulation concerning protection against damp, condensation, and contaminants like radon.
Building Regulation requiring that all materials and workmanship are of a proper standard.
Building Regulation concerning insulation against sound from other parts of the building and adjoining buildings.
Building Regulation requiring adequate ventilation for health and energy efficiency.
Building Regulation concerning the safe installation of boilers, stoves, and fireplaces.
Ladders

column3: Part L - Conservation of Fuel and Energy
column4: Building Regulation concerning the energy efficiency of buildings.
Building Regulation concerning access and facilities for people with disabilities.
The process of adding measurements to a drawing.
A way of representing a 3D object in 2D by drawing it from different views (e.g., front, top, side). Plan and elevation drawings are examples.
Utilities supplied to a site, such as water, electricity, gas, and telecommunications.
A legal agreement that gives a utility company the right to install and maintain pipes or cables across private land.
A small opening at the base of a cavity wall's outer leaf to allow moisture to drain out.
Insulation material placed or installed within the cavity of a cavity wall, such as rigid boards or pumped beads/foam.
A tapered piece of wood fixed on top of a flat roof joist to create a slope or 'fall' for drainage.
A roof construction method where the insulation is placed on top of the roof deck or structure.
A roof construction method where the insulation is placed between the joists or rafters, below the roof deck.
Inert granular materials such as sand, gravel, or crushed stone that, along with cement and water, are an essential ingredient in concrete.
A substance added to concrete, mortar, or grout to alter its properties, such as a plasticiser to improve workability or an accelerator to speed up setting time.
The direction, size, arrangement, and appearance of the fibres in a piece of wood.
The gradual destruction of a metal by chemical reaction with its environment, e.g., rusting of iron.
A dense fluid which is used to fill gaps or used as reinforcement in existing structures.
A flexible, waterproof sealant used to fill gaps and joints, for example around window frames or sanitary ware.
The movement of air into and out of buildings, chimneys, flue-gas stacks, or other containers, resulting from air buoyancy.
Using the sun's energy for the heating and cooling of living spaces by exposure to the sun. Windows, walls, and floors are made to collect, store, and distribute solar energy.
A hazardous mineral fibre that was used in various building materials. It is dangerous when disturbed and the fibres are inhaled.
A gap in a structure or material designed to allow for movement due to thermal expansion and contraction.
The horizontal layer of mortar on which bricks or blocks are laid.
The external corner of a wall.
A trough fixed to the fascia to collect and carry away rainwater.
A pipe to carry rainwater from a roof gutter down to a drain.
The strip of wood or stone at the bottom of a doorway, which you step over to enter a room.
A level area at the top of a staircase or between one flight of stairs and another.
The process of applying a screed to a floor.
A type of moulding fixed horizontally to the wall around the perimeter of a room.
A covered opening that allows access to an underground utility, such as a sewer or drainage system.
A trench filled with gravel or rock, containing a perforated pipe, that redirects surface water and groundwater away from an area.
A map showing the location of the construction site in relation to the surrounding area.
Control of Substances Hazardous to Health. Regulations that require employers to control substances that are hazardous to health.
The upper, outermost layer of soil, usually the top 2 to 8 inches. It is stripped from the site before construction begins and stored for later use in landscaping.
The uniform thickness of a mortar joint in brickwork.
A passive fire protection system of sealing openings and joints in fire-resistance-rated wall or floor assemblies.
The angle of a roof slope.
A decorative iron piece fixed at the bottom of a roof hip.
The separation of the constituent materials of concrete, where the coarse aggregate separates from the sand-cement mortar.
A form of segregation in which some of the water in the concrete tends to rise to the surface of freshly placed concrete.
Unplasticized Polyvinyl Chloride. A rigid form of PVC often used for window frames and pipes.
Strips of material used to seal the gaps around doors and windows to prevent draughts.
The first step at the bottom of a staircase, which is wider and has a curved or 'curtailed' end.
A decorative moulding that runs around the junction between a wall and a ceiling.
Energy from a source that is not depleted when used, such as wind or solar power.
Solar panels that convert sunlight directly into electricity.
Panels that use sunlight to heat water, which can then be used for domestic hot water.
A notice submitted to the local authority indicating the intention to start construction work.
A certificate signed by a qualified professional confirming that a building has been constructed in accordance with the Building Regulations.
column5: Civil rights demand for universal suffrage in local elections

column4: A document that details the way a work task or process is to be carried out, outlining the potential hazards and the precautions to be taken.
A method of waterproofing applied to basements and other structures below ground level.
A dense fluid which is used to fill gaps, such as in the cavity of a wall when building with hollow blocks.
The part of a chimney that projects above a roof.
A covering for the top of a chimney pot, designed to improve draught and prevent rain from entering.
The process of bonding together layers of material. Glulam (glued laminated timber) is an example used for structural beams.
The arrangement of windows and doors on the elevations of a building.
A seal that swells up when heated, used around fire doors to block the passage of smoke and fire.
An underground chamber through which domestic wastewater flows for basic treatment. Used in rural areas without access to the main sewer system.
A system of trenches containing perforated pipes and gravel, used to disperse the liquid effluent from a septic tank into the ground.
The design of buildings, products or environments to make them accessible to all people, regardless of age, disability or other factors.
The process of strengthening the foundation of an existing building or other structure.
A structure built against or projecting from a wall which serves to support or reinforce the wall.
A four-sided gambrel-style hip roof characterized by two slopes on each of its sides with the lower slope, punctured by dormer windows, at a steeper angle than the upper.
A reddish- or yellowish-brown flaky coating of iron oxide that is formed on iron or steel by oxidation, especially in the presence of moisture.

A composite material, poured in place or precast, which is used for floor and wall treatments. It consists of chips of marble, quartz, granite, glass, or other suitable material, poured with a cementitious binder.
A device that transfers heat from outside a building to inside, or vice versa. It can be used for space heating and hot water.
A central heating system that transfers heat from the ground into a building to provide space heating and hot water.
A detailed drawing used during the construction phase of a project.
A temporary fence erected around a construction site.
The upward swelling of soil during freezing conditions caused by an increasing presence of ice as it grows towards the surface.
A wall shared by two adjoining properties.
A vent installed in the gable of a house to help with attic ventilation.
Organic matter used as a fuel, especially in a power station for the generation of electricity.
A surface coating used for interior decorating, most often applied to ceilings. Its textured surface is created by the addition of asbestos in older versions.
Wastewater generated from domestic activities such as laundry, dishwashing, and bathing, which can be recycled on-site for uses such as toilet flushing.
The total amount of greenhouse gases (including carbon dioxide and methane) that are generated by our actions.

The maximum amount of air a person can expel from the lungs after a maximum inhalation.
The diffusion of oxygen from the alveoli into the blood and carbon dioxide from the blood into the alveoli.
The main source of energy for most cellular processes, including muscle contraction.
An anaerobic energy system that provides immediate energy for high-intensity activities lasting up to 10 seconds, by breaking down phosphocreatine.
An anaerobic energy system that breaks down glucose to produce ATP for high-intensity activities lasting from 10 seconds to 2 minutes. Lactic acid is a by-product.
The energy system that uses oxygen to break down carbohydrates, fats, and proteins to produce ATP for long-duration, low to moderate intensity activities.
The extra volume of oxygen needed to restore the body to its resting state and remove lactic acid after a period of intense exercise.

Components of physical fitness that contribute to how well the systems of the body operate. Includes cardiorespiratory endurance, muscular strength, muscular endurance, flexibility, and body composition.
Components of physical fitness that contribute to the ability to successfully participate in sports. Includes agility, balance, coordination, power, reaction time, and speed.
The ability of the heart, lungs, and blood vessels to deliver oxygen to working muscles during sustained physical activity.
The maximum amount of force a muscle or muscle group can exert in a single effort.
The ability of a muscle or muscle group to perform repeated contractions against a resistance for an extended period of time.
The range of motion available at a joint.
The relative amounts of muscle, fat, bone, and other vital parts of the body.
The ability to change the position of the body quickly and accurately.
The ability to maintain equilibrium while stationary (static) or moving (dynamic).
The ability to use two or more body parts together smoothly and efficiently.
The ability to exert maximum muscular contraction instantly in an explosive burst of movements. (Power = Strength x Speed).
The time elapsed between a stimulus and the beginning of the reaction to it.
The ability to perform a movement or cover a distance in a short period of time.
The principle that training must be relevant to the individual and their sport to produce the desired effect.
The principle that in order to improve, athletes must continually work harder as their bodies adjust to existing workouts.
The principle that fitness improvements are lost when training stops.
A framework for designing training programs, standing for Frequency, Intensity, Time, and Type.
The organised division of training into blocks, each with a goal and time-frame. Phases include macrocycle, mesocycle, and microcycle.
Training at a steady pace for a sustained period of time (at least 20 minutes) in the aerobic training zone.
Training that involves alternating between periods of high-intensity work and periods of rest or lower-intensity work.
A variation of continuous training that involves changes in intensity or speed over different terrains. Swedish for 'speed play'.
A series of exercises performed one after the other with a brief rest in between.
A form of strength training using weights to provide resistance to the muscles.
Exercises in which muscles exert maximum force in short intervals of time, with the goal of increasing power (speed-strength).
Nutrients required in large amounts that provide energy: carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.
Nutrients required in small amounts: vitamins and minerals.
The body's main source of energy, found in foods like bread, pasta, and fruits.
Nutrients essential for growth and repair of body tissues, found in foods like meat, fish, and eggs.
Nutrients that provide a source of energy and are essential for absorbing certain vitamins. Found in oils, nuts, and dairy products.
A diet that contains the right quantities and proportions of the required nutrients to maintain health and wellbeing.
The process of replacing water in the body to maintain fluid balance.
A harmful reduction in the amount of water in the body.
A rating system for foods containing carbohydrates, showing how quickly each food affects your blood sugar (glucose) level.
A strategy used by endurance athletes to maximise the storage of glycogen in the muscles and liver before an event.
The study of the mechanical laws relating to the movement or structure of living organisms.
An interaction that will change the motion of an object. It can be a push or a pull.
The rate at which an object changes its position; speed in a given direction.
The rate of change of velocity.
The quantity of motion of a moving body, measured as a product of its mass and velocity.
A rigid bar that turns about an axis of rotation or a fulcrum. The body uses a system of levers to create movement.
A lever in which the fulcrum is located between the effort and the resistance. (EFR). E.g. nodding the head.
A lever in which the resistance is located between the fulcrum and the effort. (FRE). E.g. plantar flexion at the ankle.
A lever in which the effort is applied between the fulcrum and the resistance. (FER). Most common in the body. E.g. bicep curl.
The point at which the mass of a body is considered to be concentrated.
The ability of a body to resist being moved or to return to its original position after being displaced.
An object will remain at rest or in a state of uniform motion unless acted upon by an external force.
The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the force causing it and is in the same direction, and inversely proportional to the mass of the object (F=ma).
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
The learned ability to bring about pre-determined results with maximum certainty, often with the minimum outlay of time or energy or both.
A skill performed in an unpredictable environment where the performer must adapt their movements. E.g. a pass in football.
A skill performed in a stable, predictable environment. E.g. a free throw in basketball.
A skill that involves large muscle movements. E.g. running, jumping.
A skill that involves small, precise muscle movements. E.g. darts, snooker.
The first stage of learning, where the performer is trying to understand the skill and makes many errors.
The second stage of learning, where the performer is practicing the skill and can detect and correct some of their own errors.
The final stage of learning, where the skill has become automatic and the performer can concentrate on tactics and strategy.
Information a performer receives about their performance. Can be intrinsic or extrinsic.
Feedback that comes from within the performer, based on their own feelings and sensory information.
Feedback that comes from an external source, such as a coach or teammate.
Feedback that reinforces correct performance and is used to motivate the performer.
Feedback that focuses on errors and is used to correct performance.
The effect that learning one skill has on the learning of another.
The internal and external factors that direct and energise behaviour.
Motivation that comes from within the performer, such as personal satisfaction and enjoyment.
Motivation that comes from an external source, such as tangible rewards (trophies, money) or intangible rewards (praise).
A state of alertness and anticipation that prepares the body for action.
A theory suggesting that performance improves as arousal increases, but only up to an optimal point. After this point, performance deteriorates.
A negative emotional state characterized by nervousness, worry, and apprehension, associated with activation or arousal of the body.
The mental component of anxiety, including worry, negative thoughts, and self-doubt.
The physical component of anxiety, including physiological responses like increased heart rate, sweating, and muscular tension.
The process of identifying something that you want to accomplish and establishing measurable goals and timeframes.
A goal-setting framework: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic, Time-bound.
The process of using all the senses to create or re-create an experience in the mind.
The internal dialogue a person has with themselves, which can be positive or negative.
The ability to focus on relevant cues in the environment (selective attention) and maintain that focus over time.
Substances, devices, or practices that enhance an individual's energy use, production, or recovery.
Synthetic substances similar to the male hormone testosterone, used to increase muscle mass and strength. Illegal.
Drugs that block the effects of adrenaline, leading to a lower heart rate and reduced anxiety. Banned in sports like archery and shooting.
Drugs that increase urination, used to lose weight quickly or to mask the presence of other banned substances.
Drugs that increase alertness, reduce fatigue, and may increase competitiveness and aggression.
The international organization responsible for promoting, coordinating, and monitoring the fight against drugs in sport.
Ethical, appropriate, polite and fair behaviour while participating in a game or athletic event.
The use of dubious, although not strictly illegal, methods to win or gain a serious advantage in a game or sport.
Behaviour that goes against the norms and values of society.
The process of managing or running something principally for financial gain.
The relationship and interdependence between sport, media, and sponsorship.
Fluid found in the cavities of synovial joints which reduces friction between the articular cartilage during movement.
A short band of tough, flexible fibrous connective tissue which connects two bones or cartilages or holds together a joint.
A flexible but inelastic cord of strong fibrous collagen tissue attaching a muscle to a bone.
The maximum rate of oxygen consumption measured during incremental exercise.
The number of calories required to keep your body functioning at rest.
The motion of an object thrown or projected into the air, subject only to the acceleration of gravity.
A practice schedule in which the amount of rest between practice attempts is shorter than the amount of time spent practicing.
A practice schedule in which the amount of rest between practice attempts is longer than the amount of time spent practicing.
Any form of behaviour directed toward the goal of harming or injuring another living being who is motivated to avoid such treatment.
An advanced stretching technique involving both the stretching and contracting of the muscle group being targeted.
The process where oxygen is taken in from the air and exchanged for carbon dioxide in the alveoli.
The process of bone formation.
The principle that a muscle fibre will either contract completely or not at all in response to a stimulus.
The widening of blood vessels, which increases blood flow.
The narrowing of blood vessels, which decreases blood flow.
The volume of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation.
A by-product of anaerobic glycolysis which can cause muscle fatigue.
The process whereby the body adjusts to the demands of training.

A force acting opposite to the relative motion of any object moving with respect to a surrounding fluid.
A force that is perpendicular to the direction of flow and is generated by the interaction of a fluid with an object.
Practicing a skill in its entirety.
Breaking a skill down into its sub-routines and practicing each part individually.
The degree to which members of a group are motivated to stay together and work towards common goals.
The practice of ensuring that people feel they belong, are engaged, and are connected.
The principle that training should be varied to prevent boredom and maintain motivation.
The distance an object has moved in a particular direction.
The rate of change of displacement.
The rate of change of velocity.
An object will remain at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by a net force.
The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass (F=ma).
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
The product of an object's mass and velocity (p=mv).
In a closed system, the total momentum before a collision is equal to the total momentum after the collision.
The product of the force and the distance moved in the direction of the force (W=Fs).
The ability to do work.
The energy an object has due to its motion (Ek = 1/2 mv^2).
The energy an object has due to its position in a force field (Ep = mgh).
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only changed from one form to another.
The rate at which work is done or energy is converted (P = W/t).
The force directed towards the center that keeps an object moving in a circle.
The number of complete oscillations or cycles per second.
The time taken for one complete oscillation or cycle.
Motion where the acceleration is directly proportional to the displacement from a fixed point and is always directed towards that point.
The force needed to extend or compress a spring by some distance is directly proportional to that distance (F=-ks).
The turning effect of a force, calculated by multiplying the force by the perpendicular distance from the pivot.
A rigid bar that is free to rotate about a fixed point called a fulcrum.
Mass per unit volume ( = m/V).
Force per unit area (P = F/A).
The upthrust on an object immersed in a fluid is equal to the weight of the fluid it displaces.
A wave in which the particles of the medium oscillate perpendicular to the direction of energy transfer.
A wave in which the particles of the medium oscillate parallel to the direction of energy transfer.
The distance between two consecutive points in phase.
The maximum displacement from the equilibrium position.
The bouncing of a wave off a surface.
The bending of a wave as it passes from one medium to another.
The spreading of a wave as it passes through a gap or around an obstacle.
The phenomenon that occurs when two or more waves meet and combine to form a new wave.
When two waves meet in phase, resulting in a wave of greater amplitude.
When two waves meet out of phase, resulting in a wave of smaller amplitude.
The process of restricting the oscillations of a transverse wave to a single plane.
The apparent change in frequency of a wave due to the relative motion between the source and the observer.
The subjective interpretation of the frequency of a sound.
The subjective interpretation of the amplitude of a sound.
The property that distinguishes between two sounds of the same pitch and loudness.
The transfer of energy between two bodies with the same natural frequency.
The lowest frequency at which an object can vibrate.
Frequencies that are multiples of the fundamental frequency.
Approximately 3 x 10^8 m/s in a vacuum.
The ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum to its speed in a medium (n = c/v).
n1 sin(i) = n2 sin(r), where n is the refractive index, i is the angle of incidence, and r is the angle of refraction.
The complete reflection of a light ray at the boundary of two media when the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle.
The angle of incidence for which the angle of refraction is 90 degrees.
The splitting of white light into its constituent colours.
An image formed by the actual intersection of light rays, which can be projected onto a screen.
An image formed by the apparent intersection of light rays, which cannot be projected onto a screen.
The distance from the center of a lens or mirror to its focal point.
The reciprocal of the focal length in metres (P = 1/f).
A measure of the degree of hotness or coldness of a body.
Energy transferred from a hotter body to a colder body.
The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of 1 kg of a substance by 1 Kelvin.
The heat energy absorbed or released during a change of state at constant temperature.
The heat energy required to change 1 kg of a substance from a solid to a liquid at its melting point.
The heat energy required to change 1 kg of a substance from a liquid to a gas at its boiling point.
The transfer of heat through a substance by the vibration of its particles, without any net movement of the substance.
The transfer of heat through a fluid (liquid or gas) by the movement of the fluid itself.
The transfer of heat energy by means of electromagnetic waves.
A region of space where a static electric charge experiences a force.
The force per unit positive charge at a point in an electric field (E = F/Q).
The force between two point charges is directly proportional to the product of the charges and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.
The work done in moving a unit positive charge from one point to another (V = W/Q).
The ratio of the charge on a conductor to its potential (C = Q/V).
The rate of flow of electric charge.
The ratio of the voltage across a conductor to the current flowing through it (R = V/I).
The current flowing through a conductor is directly proportional to the potential difference across it, provided the temperature remains constant.
A measure of a material's ability to oppose the flow of electric current.
The rate at which heat is produced in a conductor is proportional to the square of the current (P = I^2 R).
A material whose resistivity is between that of a conductor and an insulator.
Conduction in a pure semiconductor due to electron-hole pairs.
Conduction in a doped semiconductor.
The addition of impurities to a semiconductor to increase its conductivity.
The boundary between a p-type and an n-type semiconductor.
A device that allows current to flow in one direction only.
A region where a magnetic force can be detected.
A current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field experiences a force.
Used to determine the direction of the force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field.
A measure of the total number of magnetic field lines passing through an area.
The magnetic force per unit length per unit current on a conductor.
The production of an electromotive force (e.m.f.) across a conductor when it is exposed to a varying magnetic field.
The magnitude of the induced e.m.f. is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux.
The direction of the induced current is such that it opposes the change that caused it.
A device used to change the voltage of an alternating current supply.
The emission of electrons from the surface of a metal when electromagnetic radiation of a suitable frequency falls on it.
The minimum energy required to remove an electron from the surface of a metal.
A quantum of electromagnetic radiation.
It is impossible to measure both the position and momentum of a particle with absolute precision simultaneously.
High-frequency electromagnetic radiation produced when high-energy electrons strike a metal target.
A stable, negatively charged subatomic particle.
Streams of high-speed electrons.
The positively charged central core of an atom, containing protons and neutrons.
A positively charged subatomic particle found in the nucleus.
An uncharged subatomic particle found in the nucleus.
The number of protons in the nucleus of an atom.
The total number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom.
Atoms of the same element with the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons.
The spontaneous disintegration of unstable nuclei with the emission of radiation.
A particle consisting of two protons and two neutrons (a helium nucleus).
A high-speed electron or positron emitted during radioactive decay.
High-energy electromagnetic radiation emitted from a nucleus.
The time taken for half of the radioactive nuclei in a sample to decay.
The number of nuclei in a radioactive sample that decay per second.
The splitting of a large nucleus into two smaller nuclei with the release of energy.
The joining of two small nuclei to form a larger nucleus with the release of energy.
A self-sustaining series of nuclear fissions.
A fundamental particle that makes up protons and neutrons.
A fundamental particle that includes the electron and the neutrino.
Matter composed of antiparticles, which have the same mass as ordinary particles but opposite charge and other quantum numbers.
The creation of a particle and its antiparticle from energy.
The process that occurs when a particle collides with its antiparticle, converting their mass into energy.
The fundamental force that binds quarks together to form protons and neutrons, and holds the nucleus together.
The fundamental force responsible for radioactive decay.
The fundamental force that acts between electrically charged particles.
The fundamental force of attraction between objects with mass.
